Vim Reboot 1

Over the past few years my VIM configuration has gotten out of hand. I have tried to maintain it as best I can, but its time for a reboot! I was inspired by Avdi Grimm’s recent Emacs Reboot series and decided to do something similar with VIM.

I work on a Mac, which means I prefer to use MacVim where possible. The latest snapshot for Snow Leopard can be found at http://code.google.com/p/macvim/. Installing is as easy as you would expect. Simply download the snapshot, drag MacVim.app to Applications and move the mvim script to folder in your path.

sudo mv mvim /usr/bin

Using mvim from the command line at this point should launch MacVim as you would expect.

At this point, you have two options. You can continue with this series of posts on customizing your environment by hand, or you can check out Janus and get a very good default configuration.

The first thing I wanted to do was fix the (ugly) default colorscheme and setup MacVim to work in fullscreen mode.

Create a .gvimrc file:

touch ~/.gvimrc

And add the following options to it:

if has("gui_macvim")
    " Make fullscreen mode take up the full screen
    set fuoptions=maxhorz,maxvert

    " Command-Return toggles full screen mode
    macmenu Window.Toggle\ Full\ Screen\ Mode key=<D-CR>
endif

" Start with the toolbar hidden
set guioptions-=T

" Set the color scheme
set background=dark
color ir_black

The first thing I decided to do was decide which plugins I was using and which ones were just taking up space. This list may change, but I am currently using the following plugins on a daily basis (in no particular order):

  1. SnipMate
  2. Surround
  3. Unimpared
  4. LustyJuggler
  5. Command-T
  6. Fugitive
  7. NERD Tree
  8. NERD Commenter
  9. Endwise

If you go through that list, you’ll notice that Tim Pope is the author for a majority of them. The guy has created a ton of useful plugins and I definitely recommend trolling through his projects for anything useful.
